wikipedia_page.main: James Kidd (11 March 1872 – 2 March 1928) was a British Unionist Party politician in Scotland. He sat in the House of Commons from 1918 to 1922, and from 1924 until his death in 1928.

response: Kidd was born on 14 March 1900 in Carriden, near Bo'ness in West Lothian, Scotland. She was the elder daughter of nine children to Janet Gardner Kidd (née Turnbull, 1872–1930), a schoolteacher, and James Kidd (1872–1928), solicitor and Unionist MP for Linlithgowshire. She was educated at Linlithgow Academy and the University of Edinburgh, graduating in 1922 with an MA and LLB.

On 4 April 1936 Johnston married Doris Isobel Kidd, the daughter of James Kidd who was Conservative Member of Parliament for Linlithgowshire from 1918 to 1928. They had two sons and two daughters. During the Second World War he served in the army; on his return he was promoted to be an Advocate Depute, a crown prosecutor, in 1945. He was made a Scottish King's Counsel in October 1947.
* James Kidd (politician) (1872–1928), Unionist Party politician in Scotland
* James Kidd (prospector) (1879–1949), American prospector who disappeared in 1949
*Edinburgh educated 41-year-old James Kidd  was re-selected by the Unionists, having fought the seat at the last election.

The Linlithgowshire by-election of 1928 was held on 4 April 1928.  The by-election was held due to the death of the incumbent Conservative MP, James Kidd.  It was won by the Labour candidate Emanuel Shinwell.
